Award.AwardTitle: Fluorescent sensors for subcellular iron imaging in live-cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program and co-funding from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Maolin Guo and his group at University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth will develop fluorescent sensors for subcellular imaging of free iron ions in live cells. Iron is an essential element for many fundamental physiological processes such as oxygen transport and DNA synthesis. However, free iron is toxic to cells because it promotes the production of highly reactive free radicals which damage biomolecules. Either iron deficiency or iron over-load in the body is linked to various disease conditions.

However, measurement of iron ions in cellular or subcellular compartments is a challenging task due to the lack of analytical techniques with adequate spatial and temporal resolution and sensitivity. In this project "turn-on" and ratiometric fluorescent sensors for subcellular imaging of free iron ions in live cells using a laser confocal microscope will be designed and synthesized. Coordination-induced fluorescence activation (CIFA) or coordination-induced fluorescence resonance energy transfer (CIFRET) mechanisms will be applied to develop the iron-imaging sensors. The sensors will be capable of entering subcellular compartments such as mitochondria to image iron at subcellular level and their ability to image iron ions will be tested in live cells. Insights gained from this study will shed light on the rational design of sensors for imaging other metals and other important biomarkers. This research will provide imaging tools for investigating the complex mechanism of iron homeostasis and iron trafficking at subcellular level, which may potentially lead to the development of pharmaceuticals to treat diseases related to iron dyshomeostasis.

Research will be integrated with educational activities that provide multidisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students including women, minority and foreign students and visiting scholars in chemical synthesis and analysis, spectroscopy, microscopy, cell biology and bioimaging. In addition, high school teachers and students will actively participate in the project thus impacting K-12 education in southeastern Massachusetts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Based on several fluorescent scaffolds, we have designed and developed multiple molecular probes for the detection of Fe3+ or Fe2+ in living systems. The sensors are able to distinguish the oxidation states of iron and have a selective response to Fe3+ or Fe2+ only. The fluorescence triggered by iron is reversible, and when the iron level is lowered the fluorescence decreases (activated by Fe and deactivated by removal of Fe). Moreover, the sensors have rapid fluorescent responses to Fe3+ or Fe2+ and are capable of monitoring the intracellular trafficking of Fe3+ or Fe2+ in real time. The high specificity and sensitivity allow them to detect basal Fe3+ or Fe2+ levels at subcellular resolution in living cells, and we have observed two distinct pools of labile Fe3+ in mitochondria and lysosomes for the first time.

 

We have also developed highly sensitive and specific  ratiometric probes for the quantification of labile Fe3+ or Fe2+ in living systems. Our ratiometric probes have enabled the direct determination of the absolute concentrations of both labile Fe3+ and Fe2+ in living cells for the first time. The high sensitivity of the sensors allows for determination of basal labile iron concentrations at subcellular resolution and has revealed significantly elevated iron levels in certain cellular abnormal conditions.

 

The iron sensors developed in this project provide novel and powerful analytical tools for studying the cell biology of iron. The sensors enable the direct imaging of labile iron ions in live cells at subcellular resolution, and the direct determination of the absolute concentrations of both labile Fe3+ and Fe2+ in living systems for the first time. The capability of the sensors to detect endogenous basal iron levels, dynamic changes, and quantification of subcellular iron levels will enable advanced studies elucidating the chemistry of iron in biological processes.

 

The research has also allowed support of the next generation of scientists (from K12 students, undergraduate, graduate students to postdoctoral scholars) from diverse backgrounds in the United States and from abroad. The research project has also been integrated into my ongoing teaching activities including Modern Bioanalytical Techniques, Biochemistry II, Advanced Cell & Molecular Biology, Biochemistry laboratory, Instrumentation and Laboratory Experience, Chemistry Seminar, Graduate Seminar, and Computational Biochemistry and Bioinformatics. The students enrolled in these courses have been exposed to biosensor principles and confocal imaging techniques.
